newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Morocco telecoms cuts international calls 25 pct.
newsitem.headline: Morocco telecoms cuts international calls 25 pct.

text.p: Morocco's state-owned telecommunications (ONPT) said on Thursday it had reduced tariffs by up to 25 percent for international and some local calls and cut charges for access to GSM mobile phones.
It said the cuts had become effective on Wednesday, July 9, a public holiday.
- Local calls for distances over 200 kms (125 miles) reduced by 20 percent. Local calls for any distance cut by 70 percent instead of the existing 50 percent during public holidays.

- International calls reduced by between 11 and 25 percent depending on destination. For example, callers to Canada will benefit from a 25 percent decrease and those to Italy, France, Spain and Gibraltar by 22 percent. The cost of calls to the United States, Jordan, Yemen, Egypt have been cut by 14 percent, and those to Portugal by 11 percent.
- Subscription to GSM network are cut by 25 percent.
- Cost of calls to gain access to Internet reduced by 33 percent.
ONPT made a net profit of 700 million dirhams ($73.6 million) in 1996, up 33 percent from the previous year.
Turnover totalled 6.7 billion dirhams in 1996, up 9 percent from 1995.
Morocco plans to privatise the telecommunications and postal services, splitting the existing office into two, and starting with the GSM network.
